reviewText:
Ok where to start with Project CARS...

Graphics 10 out 10. Game is effin pretty; beyond any other racer currently out. The Weather and lighting is some of the best I've seen in any game to date.
I'm using two very old 550ti 1 gig cards and Project CARS seems to perform fairly well on those. I'm able to run at 1080p with all settings maxed except for MSAA, AA and or FXAA. I run FXAA at low and sometimes I opt to run at 1600x900 with FXAA cranked all the way up. The thing is even at 1600x900 Project CARS is still a very pretty game. For those with higher performance rigs take it up a notch and add SweetFX to the mix.

Simulation vs Simcade vs Arcade: Project CARS on the surface can hit that area of simcade a lot of players look for, but, dig a little deeper and Project CARS is a full on simulation that can be brutally difficult with no room for errors. There is nothing Arcade about Project CARS.

Views: There is a wide range of views to choose, from cockpit, helmet to third person. You can adjust the depth of fields on the fly to fine tune to your liking.

Track Selection: All the best tracks in the world, been years since I've played a game with this good of a selection on day 1.

Controls: If you're using a controller, you won't have much of an issue with just getting straight into the game. However, there is a lot to be desired still. I find the default setups to be very twitchy on an xbox 360 gamepad. I've had to put numerous hours into adjusting my controls which leads me to the next part.

UI/GUI: Project CARS has the worst GUI I have ever came across in my life long gaming career. It is confusing, lackluster, ugly and hard to use.
So for example in the controller setup there are no tooltips that explain a single thing....This is kind of what the ♥♥♥♥". So you're forced to look for guides on steam or other websites that explain how the controller setups work and what everything means...Then you can't adjust controller setting from in game. So you are forced into this cumbersome process of bouncing back and forth between this terrible GUI.
The entire UI sucks and sucks hard. There is nothing good to say about this UI. It's horrible. Car selection is even a chore
date: the tunning menus are somehow worse than the controller settings menus. This UI is pathetic
recommended: what a waste. This UI looks like something a 10th grader worked on at night after he/she got done with their homework for about 2 weeks. Then brought it to school for show and tell. COME ON GUYS. GET WITH IT. This UI brings Project CARS down in so many ways.\nSMS has made a great game here

reviewText:
After playing the game for a few hours, single and multiplayer offline/online I have come to the conclusion that this game is awesome!.

The big pluses for me are the following:

1. The sound 5.1 is amazing.
2. The menu. At first I wasn't sure but now I love it. Very easy to navigate.
3. The options in the Gameplay, graphics, HUD, career I could go on an on. They make you game experience a breeze.

10/10 for me. Great game.

ADDIT:

Have now played it for 20 hours+ and I am still loving it. The only thing that bugs me is occasionally it crashes and also sometimes in single player I have to restart the race as I have now control over the cars.

Apart fro that I still give this game a big thumbs up. keep up the good work.

Also the online racing community is really nice. Players seem to play sensibly.

reviewText:
Short Review At bottom !
Project CARS Is a intriguing Racer! Having Had it from Launch I Have encountered many Problems, At first the audio was horrible on all cars and the menu music didn't fit (Opera).
The handiling of the cars was next and this was a crucial test because a bad handling system for a racing game isn't really a racing game. Lots of the cars are very twitchy and uncontrollable but others handle lovely and make a nice racing game (GT3,Formula A) just some of my favourites. When I first had it there wasn't much going for it that made me like the game besides stunning graphics. After a few patches and trying the game with a G25 wheel,I've Grown more than fond to it but I now love the game! There are still some game braking bugs but most of those are online.

The Cars handiling Grows on you as you get used to it.
TheTrack list is decent with many variations and variety from Racetracks to A-B Roads.
The Audio has had some fixes and some of the cars sound a bit better but are still a little bit tinny" And the Menu music is still opera.
The Graphics are stunning with Rain decreasing FPS but the map looking lovely!
Bugs and a few game designs bring it down sadly
date:
Sticking every style racing game in one doesn't work like it should.
The game has many hours of fun to be played with a long career and many hours of fun online! there's much to do and many cars and tracks giving the game a good variation.

With PCARS 2 on the way I hope it fixes and solves the issues PCARS has.

A Great All round racer I recommend To Anyone who likes racing

reviewText:
I have played Grand Tursimo, Project Gotham, Grid Series and various NFS games (With a racing wheel). And my first expirence past the Go Karts.


I turn off all driving assisstances in the game including ABS and traction control systems.
I spun out alot in some car no faster than my actual car. You cant just drift around corners you'll spin out, it is a very unforgiving game you have to work to learn the corners (which gear, how much throttle, braking, steering angle, driving line). Too much throttle after a corner, spin out. Brake too hard especially in a rear wheel drive, spin out. Raining and you try to floor it off the line, spin out.  Even a poor gear change can cost you 2 positions easily. I literally sweat trying to hold poll position.

I love having to work on it. Critizing myself on how i performed each corner.

There is a no BS game, you dont have to earn money to unlock a car. All tracks and cars are avialable from the start. You dont spend an hour putting decals on your car, you'll spend 1 hour tuning your car to fit your driving style on a specific track.

The gratification in this game comes from mastering a track, not from earn 1mil to unlock a car. Getting hyped you knocked off 1 second from your lap time. It really is a racing game for racing enthuesists.

The game is literally about racing nothing else.

I get people like and are used to unlocking cars, tracks, decaling their cars and a feeling of progressing through a story. If so this is not the game for you.

Its about mastering your favourite cars on the track.

P.S - Have not expirenced any bugs/crashes

reviewText:
This is my first Steam review and although I've always enjoyed project cars on and off. Now that it has Vive support I've gone and bought all the extra content too, Not just to experience it but to say thanks to the dev team for pushing forward with the vive support which has changed me gaming life forever as an experience I recommend evangelically to anyone! :)

Also, quick notes on VR/Vive support. I recommend an absolute minimum of aliasing on 2x for now, even if you have to set everything else at minimum as it makes an insanely big difference to distance you can see and jaggies/pixels//shimmering.

The other stuff (on a 980 at least) to set high is car detail (for up close cars passing by) and maybe the rest at low or medium.

Set the screen res to 640 lowest too as that seems to be just for the preview.

Also, a small detail is that the two head" camera views are slightly different in the way they behave. One will keep your head movement relevant to the cars angle so that if you hit a bump
date: crash or go up a hill
recommended: your head moves at the same time the car does. That can be off putting for low frame rates and isn't that smooth. The other view though will make the head movement absolute so that if you go over a bump you see the car move up or down but your head stays fixed to the horizon and stays stable

reviewText:
I used to play Geoff Crammond's Grand Prix and F1 Challenge 99-02 games years ago and really enjoyed them but lately I haven't had a racing game to play and I've been missing them. So I tried all the modern racing sims and as soon as I tried Project cars I was absolutely hooked. From the lovely realistic graphics to the nose to nose racing, and the real feel of the driving I felt it blew everything else away. And after almost 130 hours I am still loving it.

Unlike many other modern games you dont get unrealistic unlocks of technology in this game or daft challenges. No this game is all about real racing. So you get a real career where you can pick the style of racing - GT, open wheel, road, endurance etc - and you progress through multiple seasons gradually getting offers to race for higher quality races. You also get invitations to race events like historic car races and single type competitions that span a few weeks.

This game has it all - loads of interesting cars, loads of famous and unusual tracks, pitting, tuning, yellow/blue flags, practice sessions, qualifying, long endurance races over several hours, extremely customisable car AI, weather, race weekends, multiplayer, solo practice sessions, and breakdowns.

It speaks volumes that one of my favourite events is the Clio Cup in this game where you race Renault Clios around all-British tracks such as Donnington, Snetterton and Oulton, when you can get so much enjoyment out of racing a little underpowered car I think that reflects the quality driving experience. But all the cars in this game are amazing and you get to learn all of them throughout the career.

In terms of downsides to the game there are very few - the car AI is varied and you will find yourself beating Clios at 90% AI around Oulton only to then struggle to beat historic Escorts at 60% around the same track. Also the AI cars dont experience breakdowns or cold tyres. You do get damaged when you collide etc but not as much as you should. Finally there is no Nascar or rally driving. But that is about it in terms of 'the bad'.

So overall I heartily recommend this racing game, its far better than anything else for the PC (or otherwise). The free updates and continual expansions really add great things to the game so it keeps developing. And the best thing about this game - you can drive around a track with realistic GT cars, then go watch the same sort of race on Motors TV and its just like it is in the game! It's a fantastic experience that never gets old.

I got a lot of fun out of this, but. Since Assetto Corsa v1.6 dramatically improved the tire modelling that is the better game now.

Somewhere along the road the handling in PCars changed to be as though the cars on on ice, this isn't helped by the extremely confusing controller configution.

AC is very playable with a joypad, PCars isn't, though it is fun with a wheel as a group of us found out on LAN night - AC is just as fun, moddable, less frustrating to play with a controller and has a better, more robust online system.

AC has Laserscanned Nurburgring amongst other laserscanned tracks, the roads feel real, not super smooth like, you know, a video game.

The licenced cars in AC are better, more desirable - and there are people adding more as mods every day - so look past the fancy graphics of PCARS because that does wear thin over time, look past the weather system because you'll constantly disable it in favour of very sunny" go and by the better overall product

reviewText:
Fun, but it's no Forza
As one of those who owns a PC and multiple consoles, I have traditionally favoured the console (particularly the Xbox) for racing games. Forza is one of my all-time favourites next to Mario Kart. The car selection is second to none (even Gran Turismo is behind) while the simulation physics are well done, with realistic damage (though not as extreme as in Project Cars with wheels flying off). Oh, did I already mention Forza has a ton of great cars without stupid sponsorship livery ruining the exterior?

I don't want to pay for Xbox Live, and have been wanting to play a racing game online for a change, so I picked up Project Cars after seeing a friend enjoy it. At $23.99 CAD, I don't regret it, but I do wish I could've paid less, because the game, while good, just isn't as good as Forza. Is there ever going to be a PC racing game that has both simulation elements and a good car selection?

Project Cars' car selection is abysmal. Seriously. There's only a handful of stock cars without promotional livery (Audi R8, BMW 1-series, Mercedes A45 plus a few others), and many of those are locked in paid DLC. I decided to suck it up and try a few of the cars with ugly livery like the Scion FRS so I could have some variety, and have gotten used to it, but I still don't like it.

One of the game rules is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as well. Cut track penalty"? Seriously? Sometimes I screw up a drift and end up in a situation where I've "cut the track" but have actually caused a setback for myself
date: and this disadvantage is made worse by my speed being limited for 5-10 seconds
recommended: which is NOT FAIR. I tried to find a way to disable this in my own lobby but to no avail.\n\nBut putting those glaring flaws aside
hoursPlayed: I am genuinely having fun with the game. The simulation mechanics are more hardcore than in Forza
voteText: with tire wear
helpfulPercent: fuel consumption
votesHelpful: and mechanical damage (including blown engines and complete losses of wheels) to worry about. Sometimes you can ram another player and send him flying into a wall at 200 km/h and cause his front wheel to snap off
votesTotal:
and then his engine blows as he tries to get back on track. It's deliciously satisfying when that happens.

The graphics are to die for. Forza doesn't come close. There's even an Xbone version of Project Cars available and that also puts Forza to shame.

The setup flexibility in races is amazing. You can have up to 23 AI opponents. You can set the race to occur at NIGHT (which means you need your headlights and you need to avoid frontal collisions that could destroy them). You can turn on light or heavy RAIN which can add an extra challenge in handling.

Overall
votesFunny: Project Cars does many things right in spite of its flaws and so I recommend it. But it could be so much better
commentsCount: if it added the Forza car selection and took out the cut track penalty."

I love driving games be they arcade, simcade or sims, although I prefer sims.
I think the negative comments are wrong. If your PC is totally up to date and you can get the best out of pCars, it's awesome. Constantly updated, (Which can be a pain as it often means reconfiguring settings lol)
People that have slated it in the past probably didn't/don't have the specs, equipment or haven't kept on giving it time with the updates.
I play on 4k 3840x2160 with 2x 980Ti's with a wheel and pedals and it's brilliant.
The new announcement about Vive support has pushed me into placing an order :0

reviewText:
I 100% recommend this game.

This was the first game I ever pre-ordered, I had seen the trailer and was stunned by its graphics and so I took the plunge - so to speak. I originally played this game on a steelseries SRW-S1 which is an accellerometer based wheel and I found the game to be excellent but once I bought myself a Logitech G29 it just totally transformed the game for me.

The game excells in it's graphics and its content. Whilst there are lots of DLC packs to be bought, they are in fact worth it. Once you have the FFB dialled in the way you want it, the game really unlocks to you. I've seen some comments suggesting that the FFB is annoying because of the default set-up, but the way SMS have set up the FFB is that you can adjust so many different global FFB settings and more specific FFB settings on a per-car basis. The result is everyone (with a little tinkering) can find the settings that suit them.

I will say that the Multiplayer can be annoying sometimes but I am more of a single-player, also the AI will shoot across corners with reckless abandon and receive no punishment from it unlike the player. Bearing these two things in mind, the game is not reaching its full potential but with out a doubt you will still definitely have fun with this game.

I know some people complain that the physics are basic. Having not played iRacing or Assetto Corsa, I can only compare this game to arcade games and for me the physics are outstanding. I really feel like I know what the car is doing.

As for bugs, I have found bugs with the RADBULL drift car and some multiplayer connection issues but that is it in 550 hours of gameplay a very few small bugs so I don't quite know what is causing them for other people.

The graphics are excellent and well optimised. I play on a laptop and have all the graphics on High and get 60fps so they have done an excellent job in optimising the game for Nvidia cards.

The gaps in vehicles including in the game might put some off (e.g. no Ferrari or Lamborghini) however if you are patient, Machine Dojo Modding Team are working on free car models to include in the game. SMS rather helpfully released an update which makes it a lot easier to install modded vehicles.

All in all the game holds it's own. The AI is a bit arcade-y and the multiplayer has some bugs in relation to people's internet connection (as many games fdo). Maybe as it is my first Racing Sim it seems more amazing then it is but to be honest from what I've seen of other sims; imo this game is very well rounded and is the best parts of acrcade and sim to make sure everyone has a good time.

Also recommend checking out ApexOnlineRacing (AOR) leagues done on pCars to get a good idea of the level of racing you can achieve on this game

reviewText:
I know there are a lot of negative reviews for this game , but mine will mostly focus on what I like about the game.

1. The AI. Yeah like everyone else has said, the AI does unfortunately cheat you sometimes. However, if you are really good at this game and get good with race lines...they really don't stand a chance. My hardest difficulty I've played AI is 90. So I guess I can say I'm alright. I've only ever played online with friends and not randoms. I enjoy the challenge though. There are times when the AI will get so far ahead that it's just unexplainable. I don't mind restarting, but I can imagine this would ruin people's gaming mood.

2.Visuals.  Projects Cars is probably one of the best visual racing games I've seen. I was hoping GT sport was going to beat PC, however I was left in utter disappointment when I found out it was just basically gt6 with an e sports feel. The trailer was highly misleading. They still have 6 months to go, but I don't have much faith. Assetto Corsa has more of a matte finish with their visuals, but it's close to PC on say, medium-ish settings with some low. I'm happy with my pruchse when it comes to visuals.

3. Driving/Gameplay. At first this game was really hard to get a hang of. I remember I tried to play it like NFS shift or Forza, it just didn't work out for me and for about 2 days I was regretting my purchase. For those first two days I was braking while making turns instead of pre breaking. I quit playing for a while and didn't touch the game for sometime. I couldn't refund because I had broke in 5 hours. One day I decided to just give the game a real chance and learn it. I'm glad I did. With the right music or just the sound of the engine alone, the cars are a real joy to drive. I use a 360 controller, but would love to have a wheel...just not willing to spend so much for one. 360 controller works just fine for me. My current favortie car in the game is the mercedes AMG GT3. Has amazing handling and reasonable HP. There are some cars in the game, no matter how much the setup is tweaked, the car is just still bad for me at least. I'd say my least favorite are the audi's and aston martins.

4.Tracks. Lots of familiar tracks from other games appear here. Sadly this is a professional racing sim. So, you will not see beautiful night time cities like the underground series of NFS had. I guess they would be a nice addition to the game, but I do like the professional feel a lot more. Makes you feel top dog, if you will. You can customize track settings to a fixed wheather setting or have it mixed which is nice. I always used fixed. Nightime will defintely make the race more interesting and have you on edge.

5. Online. Like I mentioned before, I've only played online with a friend or 2, so I can't give my opinion on the community or quality of online when there are a lot of cars. However I hear that a lot of people leave during the race. I've seen this on youtube for the console side on PS4 thanks to viperconcept. One thing I do like about online is that you can make the games private. I would probably have asked for a refund if all I could play was public games and deal with trolls occasionally.

6.360 controller. When I first got this game, the controller would at times,....eh stop working. I'd have to restart the game and it was annoying. This was also a part of my regret. Ever since I decided to give this game a real shot, I've noticed it hasn't been happening so far. I'm glad it was fixed, I hope I didn't just jinx myself.

I guess thats all I have to say. hope this gives you a better understanding of what you could have if you choose to buy.

reviewText:
After 140h of playing Project CARS I would like to share my thoughts about this game. First of all let me state that I play with a Geforce GTX980 and a T500 RS + Th8A using the natural transmission type of the individual cars (i.e. clutch + H-shifter / sequential with paddles / sequential with shifter). In addition I mostly stick to the single player career mode with the following settings:
- opponent strength of 80%
- a session length of 30%
- helmet camera
- full damage
and the following assists enabled:
- traction control,
- anti-lock brake,
- stability control
- partially visible racing line

At the beginning I started to play with all assists off except racing line but found it way too time consuming to get used to the different cars' handling in order to achieve decent results. Even with the above-mentioned assists enabled, most cars are far from having a handling like being on rails. With many cars you always have to take care of not going full throttle in bumpy corners, on curbs or revving too high in low gears. So in essence this is for me by no means a casual game, but a game where you have to be fully awake and be willing to take the full grind of training, qualifying and race. For each event I am in absolute need of the training to get a feeling for the car and the track. With some car beasts or tracks one training session isn't even enough for me.

Let's get to the pros and cons:

+ excellent graphics, especially the lighting and rain effects
+ dynamic weather and time-of-day changes
+ many different cars and car classes
+ many different tracks with different layouts
+ many of the cars and tracks are great fun to drive
+ immense feeling of immersion in helmet camera view, especially in the open wheelers
+ nice sound
+ good FFB (I use Jack Spade's tweaker files)

+/- very demanding and time consuming to master the different cars and tracks
+/- opponent AI

- the available car models in some car classes are very unbalanced in terms of performance
- the racing line braking points are quite often misplaced and thus useless
- Due to the very strict short cut detection system it can sometimes be quite time consuming to get a valid lap time at all. In addition it is really annoying that you can get a short cut penalty even when the AI pushes you from the track.
- The AI is way too quickly back on track once it gets off, while for yourself it can sometimes take ages to get back.
- Unbalanced opponent strength: At 80% opponent strength, I often am 1 or 2 seconds faster than the AI while sometimes I am 3 seconds behind. E.g. with the 90's DTM Mercedes on the Nürburgring I don't stand a chance at all, while races with the Lancer in Monza are like a walk in the park.
- For my flavour it rains too often in carrer mode. Even when it's currently sunny, if you forget to check the weather forecast for a three lap race, you can get in BIG trouble.
- Save game is only stored locally and not in the Steam cloud. Not knowing that in the beginning once cost me about 40h of career progress.
- Majority of Community Events requires owning DLCs.
- Sporadically I have the suspicion that the driving assist and/or rain tyre selection detection is bugged as the handling can be like on soap.
- Annoying menu for graphics and controller settings. You always have to leave the race for changing anything. In addition I can only partially navigate with my wheel buttons through the menu.
- No possibility to save the progress within a race. For multi-hour races you can only put the race on pause, but you have to drive from beginning to end.

Overall I give Project CARS a 7/10.

reviewText:
A great racing simulator with a variety of cars and tracks, plus a unique career mode.

Project CARS is a racing simulation made by Slightly Mad Studios, the studio which was - before the release of this game - mostly known for developing the Shift games. This time, not under the Need for Speed franchise nor Electronic Arts, they took a shift (pun intended) towards realism. And all in all, I'd say they did pretty well.

At first you're welcomed with a neat main menu which has everything separated into categories, making it easy to find anything you're looking for without having to really go and look for it. Which is nice. Although I don't think you'd get this game only to admire its menu, so let's assume that after going through the options and configurations a bit - which I had some issues with since the mapping detection seemed to have a day off but everything ended up working in the end - you'll want to try actually driving.

You can either jump into the career mode straight away, have a quick race weekend, or perhaps start up a free practice session. Whatever you choose, the experience remains completely up to you. Your career can start in any series you want; if you like, you can drive a season in Le Mans Prototypes, or maybe go racing karts and work your way up slowly all the way up to the F1 equivalent. And in the other modes, choose any car and track you want to race on - and there are loads to choose from. No unlocks, no grinding. Now some people like that approach and some don't - I found it alright, with the included accolades and achievements providing challenge and motivation to some degree. Of course, it's not like Gran Turismo, but it works. The multiplayer portion of the game is also very populated, with a game to find at pretty much any time you want to race.

Finally getting on the track, the first thing to notice is surely the audiovisual appearance. The game both sounds and looks great. Well, maybe except for the rain drops, which have went as far as ruining every single rainy race I had and I have no clue why would they want to keep that ugly effect in the game, but maybe I'm in the minority on that one... Disregarding that, the developers' attention to detail is definitely noticeable everywhere. I'd classify it as one of the prettiest racing games around, at least at the time of its release.

The gameplay itself, I don't have a word to say against the car physics, and you can further enhance how the car feels with a lot of tuning options. Every car feels entirely different. The AI is alright as well, could have been better but the opponents aren't necessarily frustrating to race against which by itself makes it superior to the most of other titles. The game can be very strict in terms of respecting the track limits, but that's probably for the better.

I dislike that some bits of the game feel unpolished, with little bugs, both gameplay and visual to encounter at times, and even missing capital letters at the beginnings of sentences or even the drivers' names. Those things certainly don't look nice but aren't too game-breaking, and the only crash I have encountered was caused by my own doings because I alt-tabbed to the desktop and the game probably didn't like it at that point. Everything else seems to be good at the technical side of things.

Project CARS is good. It can pretty much be what you want it to be, a realistic simulation - although not comparable to the likes of iRacing - or a slightly more arcadey experience if you prefer it to be that way. It has loads of cars and tracks, and, most important of all, it's also pretty fun and exciting to play. For the price you can often buy it at, it's worth it.

reviewText:
Having played this game for close to 30hrs, I feel I have enough of a grasp of it's content to write a review. For reference, I come from a Gran Turismo background so a lot of my feedback will be based on that as a 'simulator' with the use of a wheel/pedal setup (My current setup is a Thrustmaster T500RS, TH8a Shifter & T3PA PRO Pedals).

GRAPHICS - 8/10
This is easily the strong point for PCARS. I am fortunate to have a very good PC so play with mostly Ultra setting with some at high getting roughly 70-100fps. The detail within the cars is excellent with the environment and tracks being even better, a really good looking game. However I must note that even at the point of this review, there are still graphical glitches seen in open cockpit cars when it is/isn't raining.

INTERFACE/UI - 7/10
In one word I would say....simple. Everything is easy to find and straightforward. That being said, the career" segment is so basic and shallow it seems like an afterthought. WTF is that calendar system all about? Could the Devs not think of something more interesting/complex than a calendar?

Also pointless emails/"tweets" are pointless. WHY? I won 15ish races on the bounce and I still got emails from people saying "...this could be part of a streak"....??? Really? You think? Why do I care what Betty whatshername wrote about me on twitter clone-hashtag thingy? I don't!

PHYSICS - 6/10
This is where I start to see a downturn in PCARS. The physics attached to the cars are very good and definately worth the title of simulation
date: however the score I have given reflects the lack of positive impact changing the settings of any vehicle has on it's handling. I have tweaked the settings to try and improve charachteristics of the vehicle (Escort Mk1) but to no notable avail. It seems as though every car is set-up to be pretty darn competitive out-of-the-box to the point where there is no real reason to change anything
recommended: even though any positive changes seem unoticeable. Why have such an indepth choice of tweaks and settings to your car when it isn't really needed?? Also to note
hoursPlayed:
crash physics between cars is below average at best (It feels more like you are playing bumper cars!).

AI - 5/10
Boring. Just plain boring. They are okay for casual racers that just need someone to race against in offline mode
voteText: but for people looking for a challenge just go and face real humans (....or try another game?). Apart from staying pretty rigid to the raceline
helpfulPercent: they do not seem to offer much of a challenge when trying to compete for podium places. I feel this is a problem area that almost the entire race genre has
votesHelpful: probably owing to the challenge of coding such an AI. So in that regard PCARS is no different than most racer sims
votesTotal:
which in of itself is dissapointing considering PCARS is meant to be the challenger to the race-sim crown.

FEATURES/DEPTH - 5/10
...and quite frankly I feel I am being generous. You never *OWN* any of the cars within the game
votesFunny: you are purely a contract driver. As a concept this is fine
commentsCount: but it will naturally lead to a lack of depth in gameplay owing to the fact that you are simply a faceless dude that turns up around the world in a blink
column16: races then jets back home (This is the main problem with PCARS). This is unlike in Gran Turismo/Forza Motorsport ect where you earn the money and put blood
column17: sweat and tears into owning a piece of machinery. Then
column18: carefully taking your underpowered Golf Gti and turning it into a FWD beast
column19: you face the challenges with something that is YOURS. You earned it
column20: raced it
column21: improved it then won in it. The concept is rewarding and makes for improved length of gameplay and a vast array of features.\n\nPCARS has none of that. You're a faceless grunt
column22:
deal with it.

CONCLUSION - 6/10
When I first learnt of PCARS I was HYPED. The idea was brilliant with a community focussed race-sim that delivered a Daddy of all racers that I could spend vast amounts of hours being a nerd while drooling over cars I will probably never own. However
column23: I feel disappointment. It's very pretty yes
column24: but it's so...so shallow. The "Career" is pathetically boring at best alongside the AI that seem to be drafted from the deaf-dumb-polite society.\n\nDisappointed."

reviewText:
Unless you set the game up for an arcade-like experience, you probably won't find instant gratification in Project CARS. It takes patience and practice to stay on the track and be competitive. Once you do get the hang of it, there's a lot of enjoyment to be had.

My favorite aspect of Project CARS is being able to set up custom races. You have complete freedom to choose the track, cars, weather, time of day, number of opponents, difficulty, starting position, race rules, warm-up/practice/qualifying rounds, and much more. This alone offers unlimited replayability.

I notice a lot of the helpful" negative reviews are out of date. There have been numerous patches since the game was released which have addreesed issues people found.

As it stands
date: Project CARS is my most played game of 2015 so it gets a big thumb up from me. :)"

reviewText:
A half arsed attempt at a racing sim,while project cars does something's right and offers a more robust front end and track and car line up than other pc racers it however fails in the most important departments when trying to be a driving game simulator or even an enjoyable arcade or casual driving game.

I hate the sound in this game,there are not enough options to balance the sound effects in the game,the slider doesn't work as intended and with most sounds down to 50% and car engine sound at 100% I can stil hear far too much road sound and other car sounds,on top of that there is an annoying tire sound heard when cornering the car at any degree that i also can't stand,it's as if the tires on your car are wrapped in sand paper and there is no variation in this sound what so ever from car to car or gegree of turning point,very generic sounding and it wont go away.The engine sounds themself i also dislike and this contradicts general thoughts that the sound quality of the cars is very good,i trialed 6 cars from the kart and fomula series to stock and road and they all sounded very furmilar,each had very similar gear ratio sets ups and all were very quick in gear changes,i couldn't get to hear a turbo kicking in as you throttle up second or third gear to the over rev point with any meaningful sense of speed,all the cars did were go up quick and over rev with no real improvement in speed,there were no backfires or engine haults,the engines all sounded a bit winy to me with no depth.

Controls while using a 360 controller were dreadful,very twitchy controls that sometimes seemed to lose control and traction on the road for no apparent reason,i found this strange and to be the case on only certain parts of a track too and feels more like a bug,i wonder if the wheel is also like this ?

I could never recommend this game,i am a little let down by it in all regards,graphics are nothing that new,sound quality is lacking mostly in deph,controls feel like a rehash of a game called need for speed shift unleashed with a similar feeling of twitchy floatyness and middle wobble,no sense of speed vs sound design.

A shame and i am glad i waited before buying and refunding.

I come from racing games like forza on console and race 07 on pc,race 07 is a far far superior game in almost every way to this pile of garbage,i highly recommend it ! and if you want the newer and possibly the best sim racer on pc i would recommend racingroom experience here on steam,the base game is free for all to play.

reviewText:
I intially backed Project Cars through their WMD platform as a team member as I enjoyed Shift 2 & was hoping for something similar to Forza or GT on PC but more of a sim. So I was disappointed when the development shifted towards what so many racing sims on PC are, a non car customisable, choose your racing car sim. After becoming bored with the prebuilds I abandoned the forums & discovered on release that instead of receiving a copy of the game as initially promised there was a 50% off coupon in my Steam inventory. Thankfully after a few months the backers received payments from sales but as I was still disappointed from not receiving the game I avoided it until Vive support was added.

Now being one of the few racing games to support the Vive I've been enjoying the game. Racing sims are hugely improved with VR, the ability to judge distances and being able to see elevation changes, just the immersion it offers.

It's worth picking up if you have a Vive, but I won't be backing Project Cars 2.

reviewText:
Yesterday I drove around the Nurburgring combined track. I set off at dusk underneath a cloudless sky. As night moved in so did the heavy clouds, before long the rain began lashing down, the floodlights reflecting in the puddles. By midnight the storm swirled around me, lap after lap it followed me, but on I drove, navigating my way through the forests and hills of Germany. Lap after lap, setting time after time. After what felt like an age the storm rolled away and as the hours ticked on by the sun rose up and covered us (me, the car, the track) in light and shadow.

This is what a next generation driving experience feels like.

10/10 Would choose not to play Forza Apex again

reviewText:
I've been playing racing sims since I started in 1993 with IndyCar Racing, and I've played most of the ones that have been released since then. Some off the top of my head would include IndyCar Racing I & II, F1GP2, Grand Prix Legends, Sports Car GT, Richard Burns Rally, GTR/GTR 2, GT Legends, Race/GT-R Evolution/Race On/etc., RaceRoom Racing Experience, SimRaceWay, Game Stockcar (including Extreme and Reiza's truck game), Live For Speed, netKar Pro, Assetto Corsa, iRacing, rFactor 1 & 2 and NASCAR Racing 2003.

I can wholeheartedly say that among all of the sims I've ever played none have felt as alive, as deep in handling nuances and as engaging to drive as Project CARS, and it is by far my favorite sim of all time (it also inspired me to really look into the physics of racing and to develop my own spring and damper calculation tool, which I'll release at some point). I'll tend to agree with Ben Collins and Kristian Roos in that past sims were often way too difficult on and over the edge, too punishing. Like Rene Rast has commented, racing cars are designed to go and be driven fast and inspire confidence in the driver, they're specifically designed to be good at going fast, which means that until you start to get to the limits, they're not that necessarily that hard to drive. So the cars feel like they actually do have some semblance of grip as they should, but start pushing to the limits and shaving those last hundredths of a second and you'll find all the challenge you could hope for.

I love this game.

reviewText: Project Cars is an overwhelmingly good starting point for any newcomer to mostly Circuit racing.  It's the perfect blend of realism and breathtaking beauty at high speed.  An outstanding number of vehicles to choose from.  From 1960's Formula 1 to modern day Formula 1.  Le Mans LMP.  Go Karts.  Street Cars.  There is literally something for everyone in terms of racing cars.  But that is all that this game is.  Racing.  If you are wanting to get out of your vehicle and shoot someone up this isn't the game for you.  If you are expecting to do something other than a ton of laps around the same tracks... this game isn't for you.  But if you're willing to open up to what racing really is and the fact that going around a track is fundamentally all there is to it, then you may just be worthy of experiencing the beauty in that fundamental aspect.\n\nWhat is the beauty you may ask?  Well... it's the beauty of the atomic atmosphere of a circuit on a race day.  Buzzing with lights and camera flashes.  The tires on the pavement making contact, creating grip and launching you into the blurry speeds of the gods. . . . . lol.  Just race damnit.

reviewText:
I've been toying with car sims for quite a few years now, and honestly, this one is the most realistic and precise car sim I've ever used. I've raced on GTR, GTR2, GTR Evolution, GT Legends, all of which are *excellent* sims, but this one has just a little thing more regarding the feeling when you get behind the wheel. And graphically, of course, when watching replays, I find myself thinking this is footage from Eurosport channel, and then realising, oh no, this is PCars! :-) :-)
I've read some negative comments about this sim, but honestly, it does not feel any worse than all the others I've tried, and I've raked up a fair amount of time on them, on the contrary, I think the force feedback is very precise and you can really feel and anticipate loss of adherence and feel the vibrators on the tracks, the difference of track textures and the bumps.
This is of course quite subjective, as everyone is different, but if you love driving and cars, and have a decent wheel like a Logitech G27 or better, like fanatec, this won't disappoint you, I guarantee you that.
Have a nice time on the track!

reviewText:
tl;dr I really like this game!

I have been a gamer for a very long time and have played many driving games, but mostly at the arcade end of the spectrum, Burnout Paradise (arcade driving perfected) and NFS etc.

Occasionally I would dabble in closer to sim games like Forza, F1, Grid, Gran Tourismo and enjoy them, but they have their limitations of sitting in the uneasy space between arcade and sims, not quite fun enough to be arcade, no accurate to get a satisfying drive.

I have tried a few proper sims, but I always find them too hardcore and hard to get into, basically I don't find them fun enough to persevere with. I made the mistake of buying Assetto Corsa which while it simulates car driving well, has no discernable game around it, the AI is terrible.

So, I have been following Project Cars for a while and unfortunately missed out on supporting it in early access, I bought it on day of release.

After playing it for a few hours I can say this is the more serious driving game I have been waiting for for years. It isn't a full on sim, with all the baggage that carries, but I would put it at the casual end of the racing sim genre.

I play with a steering wheel (old logitech Momo) which after setting up in game works well, although the Force Feedback leave a lot to be desired, it is very weedy and inconsistent. The general driving experience is great, whether doing time attacks around a course chasing ghost cars of faster real players laps, or when driving in races against the AI. The AI is the one of the highlights of the game as they genneraly act like real drivers on the track, and not crash into you like other games do. You can adjust the AI strength from 1-100 which allows you to fine tune the experience so you get a good race. I haven't tried MP yet.

My only major disappointment is the Kart Racing which unfortunately you have to do a load of races in to progress through the career mode. The Karts hand terribly with a wheel, I found I had to use my 360 controller instead, which fortunately makes the Karts playable, though still very tricky to drive. The AI in Karts doesn't work too well either. Personally I don't think they should have included Karts in the game, it detracts from the masterpiece that driving the cars in game is.

There is a wide array of tracks in the game and a decent selection of cars, although 95% of the cars are in the very fast to warp speed classes, and only a handful are at the slower end where I like doing a lot of my racing.

I know the hardcore sim snobs look down their noses at Project Cars, but IMO they should be more supportive of it even if they don't play it themselves. It acts as a great introduction to the more serious side of racing and will probably lead to more people moving to sims down the line, which is good news for their niche ecosystem.

Overall I can really recommend this game to someone who want a more serious driving game that isn't intimidating.

Pros
Great gameplay
Top of class AI
Great graphics, makes you feel like you are really racing in a car.

Cons
Kart Racing with a steering wheel
Force Feedback
Not enough slower cars for my tastes
voteText: 37 of 71 people (52%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This is the first PC racing game I've played that's been able to fill the gap left by Forza Motorsport, now that it's an XBone exclusive (because there's no way I'm buying one of those).

Controls are tight, to the point where I'm considering picking up a racing wheel for this game alone because a controller is not doing it justice. More configuration than you can poke a stick at, I honestly don't know what half of it does.

Graphics are incredible but you'll need a high end rig to do a packed race without framerate drops on ultra settings. If you have less than a dozen cars it's usually fine. I get a solid 60fps driving in heavy rain with 12 cars on the track on the highest possible settings with a GTX 980.

Plenty of beautiful tracks to race on, including Bathurst for any Aussies out there.

Personally I'm a little bit let down by the variety of cars, but there's definitely plenty to choose from. You'll be going without brands like Ferrari and Lamborghini... and even more of a let down for me was the lack of V8 Supercars (something that is offered in many other Steam racing titles such as Grid Autosport). You can't have Mount Panorama with no Holden or Ford V8 to drive! EDIT: DLC adds some extra variety, such as the Old Vs New car pack adding some Fords. Very cheap too, the base price without discount is only $4. You'd be paying on average around $1 per extra car WITHOUT a discount.

Definitely worth picking up for $50 or less. I bought it on day one and have enjoyed it since (usually play in offline mode connected to a TV so my hours don't reflect how much time I've spent ingame)

reviewText:
Excellent racing/motorsport simulator buried within a not-quite-finished game.  It is fantastic when it is good, but there are many small issues that need either work-arounds, or outright avoidance.

Pros:
- Great track selection
- Great selection of track day & race cars
- Outstanding graphics
- Tons of options
- Rift support!

Cons:
- UI is cumbersome and frustrating
- Ongoing bugs
- Flags/pitstops not well implemented

Overall, I recommend the game based on its technical achievement and excellence when all of the features come together.  Just be prepared for an experience that may be rough around the edges.

reviewText:
The best racing game I have ever played, with the irritating caveat for new users that its default G27 ffb effects are terrible and the ffb system takes a lot of headache inducing tweaking to rectify.

[comparisons influenced by comparing to Grid Autosport]

+ UI is nicely designed and very well integrated with online elements which allows a much more social experience for example competing with community ghost cars and quick access to online play, colours are bright and graphical elements are well thought out and modern in the form of a tablet icon layout.

+ With some Ultra settings on Tracks and Cars (i7 4770 nv 760 ) graphical detail is excellent much better than GA, nice clean well modelled cars, track surfaces and general layout are excellent, almost photo realistic even on a small monitor

- Despite high anisotropy I find there is some jaggys" at distance that can make judging distance to oncoming corners sometimes difficult

+ Car interiors are excellent really add to immersion
date: find myself playing in these all the time despite other views such as bumper view being arguably clearer
recommended: much better immersion factor compared to GA\n\n- Lack of split screen mode hurts long term playability if you have 2 wheels and friends
hoursPlayed: a great shame for a game with so many other features\n\n+ Pit stops requesting fuel and repairs in online races
voteText: plus presence of practice and qualifying rounds online before races really adds to immersion makes for a fantastic race experience\n\n+ Level of detail in customising cars
helpfulPercent: such as camber and toe settings
votesHelpful: downforce
votesTotal: tire temperatures for inner
votesFunny: med
commentsCount: outer and so on and on are almost endless
column16: the defaults for each car are pretty good though I found the default gear ratios sometimes off for some cars and tracks
column17: the potential depth of gameplay to be had by endless tuning is excellent
column18: though daunting the defaults are okay! Menus presented in a decent fashion as well.\n\n+ Online community is good
column19: good online integration\n\n+ Physics model compared to GA is much better
column20: physical modelling of tires and contact forces
column21: cars handle very well really adds depth
column22: tire scrubbing if turning in too fast
column23: loss of traction
column24: cars suspension bottoming out
column27: many nuances are shown for each car
column28: cars look great in replays and adds a level of detail in car handling not present in many games
column29: really cool!\n\n+ Audio [edited after 2.0] Car engine sounds are great and diverse
column31: typically hearing crowd sounds over tire sounds is very problematic. After 2.0 tire sounds are much better to hear but still difficult to pick out over the din of the crowd
column32: still wishing tire sounds and states were better transmitted through audio as it helps to get a feel for the car. Loss of traction sounds
column33: brake lockup sounds and other sounds are more noticeable now post 2.0 which is a lot better than before.\n\n+ Offline is extensive regards career mode
column34: nice offline practice and quick race functionality\n\n+ Car selection is amazing
column36: all have great interiors and outstanding 3d models and textures
column37: repaints available for each car are amazing and look amazing.\n\n+ On a 4770 + nv 760
column38: with some Ultra settings but no [ott] particle effects I am getting 100fps + offline
column39: dipping to well above 60 in online with many cars
column40: I would say it is well optimized even more of a shame they never fit in split screen as it seems reasonable spec computers can get good framerates.\n\n+ Good menus for fiddling with controls
column41:
defaults for many peripherals

***************************

EDITED After 2.0 (removed rant and recondensed with more positive outlook after recent changes);

Prior to 2.0 and as a new user coming from GA to Project Cars with the G-27 I had a lot of trouble getting the force feedback to a reasonable state which made left me very sour.

As a more experienced player now finally getting a better ffb experience through my own tweaking and understanding the numerous parameters I have removed the rant with my new outlook
column43: many of the default tire forces
column45: obliterate subtle helpful force variations for example tire torque
column46: and have to be radically tweaked to get better feel
column47: I recommend only Mz and Sop Lateral forces on each car at 100
column48: zero out all the other parameters or your wheel will get saturated.\n\n- FFB options are many falling into two primary filtering techniques
column49: relative mode and soft clipping mode
column50: by default the relative mode is used though I found this unsuitable with jumping between cars with wildly different tire forces (ex. FA to Road Car) resulting in clipping. Basically the over 20 sliders dealing with FFB are a headache for new users and require a lot of tinkering and exploring to make them feel better.\n\n[I think FFB feel is a subjective thing
column51: if its of any help I used the soft clipping settings of; SCH2
column56: Knee settings of position 70 and strength 30. Though these are ok for me as of patch 2.0 subsequent patches may alter tire forces and render these useless!] [These are also in conjuction with default car ffb strength and only 100 Mz and 100 Sop Scale + 100 Sop Lateral
column57: too many other car ffb forces here I find washes out much detail]\n\n[I even ended up charting my own G27 force linearity
column59: it has a very linear response at ~70% force upwards at a logitech profiler strength of 106 (I found this the most linear response strength) Below this its all over the place with higher force output than input
column60: I used a knee reduction of strength of 30% at the 70% mark to match aprox my own wheel and it feels ok
column61: different profiler strengths produce much different outputs
column62: the default 100 produces some odd dips and rises as well. Not to mention the force deadzone
column63: though this can be treated with increasing the force strength
column65: 106 is not as much deadzone reduction as higher but has best linearity]\n\n- Learning about ffb effects and interactions as a new user is as you can believe a bit of a bore lol! Once you are past the hump the game is good and the ffb is good too
column66:
though the game at default makes too high a demand of a new user with a G27 (and other wheels?) to get good force feedback across different cars without asking for a ******* degree in tweaking :(

Rant over but better than before!

**********************************************

TLDR Version;

+Game is the best racing game I have ever played

reviewText: I genuinely like everything about this awesome racing game.  Initially I didn't like the menu system/GUI, but it really doesn't take long to get used to it.  Sounds, graphics and physics are amazing and I've played every racing game from the hyper-realistic SimBin games to the more accessible NFS and TDU series.  This game is closer to the realistic end, but still very customizable to suit any playing level.  I believe they could do a bit more with the Career mode as it's not quite at the same level as say the Dirt series, but overall it's very well done and should keep you interested in progressing through the game.  I love the replay capability (as most racers have), as the game is so pretty I always look forward to finishing a race just so I can go back and watch the replay and maybe grab a screenshot.  Definitely worth the price of entry for any racing fan!

reviewText: this is one of the best racing sims ive ever played. i own assetto corsa and forza but this game takes the crown in all categories in my opinion. both games lacked some umph and this game delivers. the graphics are stunning. using my wheel the game drives amazing and feels more real than anything ive felt before. the amount of tracks is rediculous and while theres maybe only 50 cars they are very good ones to have in a sim and they all feel unique. the experience is rather exspansive, from actual pit stops to qualifying rounds to tuning you cars setup to the astonishing AI, this game has it all and will leave you with a smile on your face. i will say there are some negatives. first everyones heard of the amd gpu issues which luckily i dont have to worry about, but its ****** for anyone that runs a amd card. next is there isnt many players online very often, enough to play games with but not enough to have a real choice of what you play due to lonely servers. the game also has a boot issue where once it starts it minimizes to desktop and you have to reset nvidia backend software for it to maximize again which can be achieved with gamebooster( razer cortex). these are the ONLY issues with the game that i have and im very picky about the sim racers i play. so if you like sim racers dont you dare miss out on this one. its ******* awesome. just be patient for the few hickups its having at launch. im still a very satisfied customer of wmd and mad studios. my setup is i7 4770k 16gb ram gtx780 and a g27 steering wheel. i run the game at high settings 1080p at a CONSTANT 60fps.  message me if you have questions about the game boot issues.

reviewText:
By and large, I find this to be an enjoyable game.  By no means perfect, but still quite enjoyable.

Pros:
-Great graphics and sound
-Nice handling models (although I find the Superkarts to be too twitchy with a gamepad)
-Nice customization options (the game, not so much the cars within the game)
-Pretty good AI
-Great weather effects that really change the way the cars handle.

Cons:
-Not much variety in cars.
-I wish there were more variety in tracks -- I really enjoy the 'street' tracks (California and Azure Coast) and would like more of those.
-Not much of an online community from what I can tell.  On multiple occasions I waited for a random game but there never were enough people in the lobby to get the race started.
-Campaign more isn't very deep.  Very little sense of progression.

reviewText:
Project Cars is great. I did have to upgrade from my old GTX 760 to a GTX 970 in order to play this on mostly high and ultra settings, but for the visuals this game provides it was well worth it. Feedback while driving is good, the amount of detail put into each and every car, track, and the environment is fantastic. Also owning Asseto Corsa, I would recommend this game over AC any day of the week. In Project Cars, the menu system is much better laid out, it loads faster, and is far more polished. My only complaint is that I wish it had more cars - but I'm sure they will add some in the future. I'm getting a Logitech G27 this weekend and will likely report back with an update on how well it works with that as I've just been using a controller thus far. So far, I am much more pleased with this over Asseto Corsa (which is okay in its own right, as well).

To those of you comparing this to iRacing, I think you're trying to compare apples to oranges. I've always known and been told that iRacing is more of a legit racing simulator, and know several semi-pro drivers that actually used that game to learn some skills on. I honestly wouldn't put Project Cars or Asseto Corsa into that same category at all - they are likie Forza; a racing 'simulator' for those who really enjoy driving games. Games. I just believe this is one of the most well done racing sim games for the PC available to date.

So far, I haven't noticed any of the bugs that other users have mentioned, but I haven't tried playing online yet. Gameplay has been smooth and predictable without major issues.

reviewText:
Awesome simulator!  Yes that's right its a sim.  Ignore everyone else who says it isn't.  Get yourself a wheel, turn off all the assists and drive round Spa in the Wet....yep told you.  The game does have issues (what new game doesn't nowadays), sad but true.  There has already been a patch on PC with more to come no doubt.

You will have to spend some time setting up the FFB if you have a wheel, I use the G27.  I'm on the PC and I haven't played with a pad so I can't comment on that, I can imagine the karts would be tricky with a pad but with a wheel they are crazy fun!  The actual driving part of this game which is surely the main bit is absolutely phenomenal!  One of the best interpretations of road racing I have played on PC period.  There are a large selection of cars all exquisitely modelled and they sound great too.  You don't have to unlock anything, it's all there at the beginning which is a refreshing change in my opinion.

So like I said once you setup the feedback and dial in some settings the game comes alive.  If you expect to just jump straight in and expect to make competitive laps you will fail.  There is a learning curve but that's how I like it.  What you waiting for?  Go and buy it now.
voteText: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Best racing game available. Cannot say more. Some bugs in the beginning got a hotfix. Now everything works fine (up to 96%). Day-night changes are impressive.

Still, some lags make it uncomfortable to drive. Matchmaking is not that easy because you gotta search for a game that fits your preferences. Steering/handling is a bit different from what you know from other games (Grid, F1...) but after a short time you get used to it.

To beat iRacing, it needs oval races, but overall for me this is THE BEST RACING GAME at this time.

reviewText: Very delightful driving experience with a pad. Requires a lot of concentration even going down long straights as the car will automatically shift in directions if you're not controlling the steering. After playing a lot of games driving with traction control, abs and stability control this game will make you want to turn all them features off and try to drive like a proper racer and experience the true control of a car.\n\nGraphics are fantastically stunning and runs max on my GTX 980 but when you race with 20+ car in the rain you will suffer a huge fps drop so dropping the AA down to one of its lower setting (still looks fabulous and no noticeable difference) and you can race with healthy frame rates.

reviewText:
For more details check out my review video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTOGV8ZLr5Y

Project CARS is a beautiful and in depth racing simulator with enough cars, tracks and racing disciplines to keep you entertained for months. With a slew of gameplay and realism options available you can pretty much craft your perfect driving experience.

An exhaustive career mode features eight tiers of competetive racing and a fully customisable free race mode alows you to create any racing conditions you desire, including karting across the California coast in a thunderstorm!

The tuning/engineering aspects could have done with some tuturialisation and the lack of a test track is glaring mistake.

Those of you looking for an arcade racer may want to stay away, especially at full price, but those of you looking for some depth should definitely take a look.

reviewText: I haven't had a ton of time on this yet but from 5 hours of trying out most of the modes I have nothing bad to say about the game! The front end menus look slick and are very easy and smooth to navigate! There's a great selection of tracks and a decent selection of cars. This definitely isn't the car collecting game though as you won't find nearly as many cars as Gran Turismo, but every car that is relevant to racing is basically here (Kart, Touring, Rally, F1, Nascar, All open Wheel Racers etc. etc....) I am playing the game on windows 7 64 bit, with an i3 3220, Nvidia GTX 650ti and 16 GB of ram and my Resolution is set at 1080P, Textures are set to high, Car detail is high and everything else is on medium, I've disabled vsync and I have anti aliasing enabled (nothing crazy just minimal) and I also have a texture filter on. With Those settings and Specs I've never been lower than 53 FPS in-game and my HIgh side is around 85 FPS and my Average is about 74 FPS. Considering That I don't have a true quad core and I paid 150 for my card over a year ago I would say that is really and it actually exceeded my expectations. The last thing I want to mention is that my on;line experiennce has been perfect as well, its very easy to create/invite/join games and I* haven't been plagued by any lag whatsoever! Awesome Game!!!!! I would definitely reccommend it to any fan of racing/driving games. MY score for this is a 9.3 out of 10 and if it had more cars and tracks and perhaps a bigger more expansive single player/career mode I would call it perfect :p

reviewText: First of HOLY ♥♥♥♥ this game is beautiful, and as long as you just stand still and watch the pretty cars it is all good. But as soon as you begin your first race you will realize that there is something completly wrong with this game. i play with an xbox controller and sometimes the game ignores my inputs and refuses to make a turn so you have to put your stick back to the center and try to get repeat the input this is not a hardware problem i have tested this bug with 3 different controller one of them being a PS controller and they all encounter the same bug. Also sometimes the game will armwrestle the controls from you and force you to make a turn when you want to go steaight for some time. and then there is time... when i am playing the singel player time will begin to slow as i enter the begining of a turn and this effect has no duration bar or anything it is just like bam 50% time speed and bam back to normal, they could atleast give it a more fluid transition. I thought i would give racing another chance even though it have never really been my favorite genre of gaming.\ni sincerely hope they will fix some of these bug, so the game becomes playable at some point

reviewText:
I slammed Grid Autosport for being a poorly executed racing game, with bad menus, no cockpit view etc. Project cars takes all that... and does it right.

I have been freaking loving this game. The graphics are fantastic, the racing is realistic and generally it's REALLY fun.

I've spent the bulk of my time in online mode. Since I'm actually going to Spa soon, I've been racing round it online. Sometimes people rubberband at the start of the race and it does wreck people, but apart from that, the game is good, it was compatible with my racing wheel out of the box, and the online racing was thoroughly enthralling. With practise I'm doing consistently perfect laps, and posting rediculously good times.

Other things: The cars take realistic damage which is good, and it is possible to blow an engine or gearbox by jumping to first at 150MPH.

It's a damn good fun game, a little addicting actually, and I really recommend playing online!

reviewText: It's true there is no perfect sim, they do all have their good and bad points but wow all the hate talk...really. The force feedback was a bit lame at first and you kind of need to be a race engineer to set it up nicely but when its set up....OMG its phenomenal. Yes there is a mountain of various settings to properly tune the cars but again, when done correctly.....wow! This is a sim, you are meant to have to tweak till the cows come home in order to set good times. I've encounted very few bugs since first installing the game and have had nothing but a damn good time playing this title. Assetto, iRacing, Raceroom, Forza, Gran Turismo, Dirt, I play them all and others, yep, they are all good games but this is something else, and it will only improve as subsequent patches roll out. Maybe I was blessed with a special platinum edition of the game or something but I fail to see where all the negative crap I keep hearing comes from.

reviewText:
if racing experience is what you are after, then this game is for your. The racing in this game feels great and not like in any other game. AI can occasionally ram you or be too aggressive, but in that it's simulating what real players do in online races ( not talking about the usual first turn incidents, talking about proper MP raricng)

game still has some bugs to be ironed out, so perhaps you might want to wait for some time before you buy it, but if you like racing games in general, this title shouldn't miss from your library

racing is what they promise and oh boy they deliver it !

I have been playing other sims such as rFactor2 (demo only), AC, iRacing, and while each of them have great things about them, they also have bad things about them ( as does pCARS btw)

but if you can afford to have more racing games, and I think you should always have most if not all of them, they you will definitely enjoy racing around,

track selection is unmatched
car selection is solid, although some exotic cars are missing ( ferrari, lambo)
visually it's stunning, great weather effects
full day-night transition makes it perfect for endurance racing

MP can't comment on much, since I'm not much of a Mp player myself, but neat feature is Driver rating, that based on how clean or bad you drive, you will be put into MP with same sort of players

9/10 for now and once it's all polished it will be 10/10 for me
highly recommend it
voteText: 17 of 32 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is unlike any other racing game. Now I know you here that phrase used all the time and trust me I get tired of hearing it too but trust me, this is unlike any racing game out there. The immersion is so incredible and the graphics are so good that (no joke) it actually looks like real life. I looked up Project CARS on google just to see some amazing screenshots and one of them was actually real life but for the first 10 to 15 secs I thought it was the game...

-UI: The UI is very clean and crisp. Everything is easy to find and manage. Only gripe is that changing your liveries for cars requires you to go to your garage and change it from there instead of the quick car list. (Not a big deal but still worth mentioning). 10/10

-Singleplayer: I haven't even started a career yet but I assume it's amazing. As for just random racing, it's amazing. You can add up to 55 cars (most I've seen at least) on the track at once which was at Le Mans and can also have multi class so you can simulate the 24 Hours of Le Mans or 24 Hours of Nurburgring. 9/10

-AI: AI is a bit iffy. They are quite a challenge if you have it at 100 and do make mistakes on there own but seem to not even care your on the road. 7/10

-Multiplayer: This is where I have spent the most time on, mainly cause it is actual people and I like that more. Everything runs smooth and the people for the most part are nice and aren't trolls/wreck everything. Getting together with your buddies is a breeze. This is by far my favorite part of the game. 10/10

Bugs/Crashes: The only crash I have experienced was on Spa Francorchamps and my screen froze but the audio continued. I had to CTRL+ALT+DEL to close it which kinda sucked but over all that is nothing compared to all the fun I have had.

Basic Specs of my Setup: NVIDIA GTX 970 (EVGA)

i5 4590

8gb RAM

reviewText:
If you are going to buy this game please understand that this is not Need for Speed Underground and that in order to play it properly you need to invest some time in understanding cars and tracks.  Don't be suprised when your tyres or engine blows up after a long race if you haven't invested any time trying to setup the car for a particular race/track.

Do ignore people who are complaining that the developers announced Project Cars 2.  The only difference between these guys and other game companies is that these guys are honest and they let their clients know whats coming so that can get involved again.  It most certainly doesn't mean that they forgot about this game.  There is another DLC coming out tomorrow.

It greatly annoys me to see these ignorant, moronic reviews which only indicate intellect of people buying the game not the actual game.

Ignore the children complaining about a hard game.  If you like good racing games, this is a game you won't regret buying.

reviewText:
I'll share my somewhat unique experience with this game, although perhaps not exactly a game review.  Shortly before purchasing Project Cars I became a fan of the show Top Gear.  Before watching the show, I had no interest in cars whatsoever.  Over the course of a few months and 21 series of Top Gear I developed a taste for cars and was learning the basics of racing terminology and mechanics.

Top Gear introduced me to the idea of track days.  I researched them and found at there are events every weekend where I live in Southern California.  I signed up for one at random and starting researching the track.  Shortly, I realized I had signed up to go to Willow Springs, which of course is in Project Cars.  I did over 250 laps in Project Cars on Willow Springs in the classic Ford Escort before I went and did my track day there.  For those interested, I drove my land yacht Kia Amanti at the track haha.

Project Cars was an OUTSTANDING preparatory tool for me.  As a novice to track days I was required to attend some short classes before we started and after each session.   The instructors would ask us about the turns, the straights, how our different types of passing were going, and so forth.  I restrained my arrogance verbally but could not help thinking in my head that I was miles ahead of my peers.  The teacher would explain what an apex was and use turn 9 as an example.  And I would listen thinking I already know where the apex is on that turn
date: I also know that the track dips just before the apex
recommended:
I have decent idea of the speed I can take the corner at thanks to the accuracy of PCars and the similarities of my car to the Ford Escort.  I knew every turn.  Their apexes and exits.  I knew the race line.  I knew where the pits where.  And I also knew my limitations.  I knew the dangers of turn 1 and how likely I was to go off.  I knew that I could stay flat out through turn 2 and that I had to find the apex out of the passenger side window.   My first track was one of the most fun days of my life despite being in a terrible car.  And I have no doubt that my experience was deeply enhanced by my preparation in Project Cars.

Only flaw with Project Cars - No Top Gear test track in the game.  Make it a DLC.  Someone make a mod.  Something.  I wanna drive that track soooooooooooooooooo bad.

tl:dr Project Cars unquestionably made me very well prepared for my first track day in real life and has helped to further my enthusiasm for cars.  And its fun.  9.9/10"
hoursPlayed: June 2, 2015

reviewText: Game: personal 9/10, game actualy deserves 10/10. This is what everyone who spent hours on end in forza or gran turismo racing to get that .001 of a second wanted. I gave it a 9, because known of this game for about 5-8 years hype builds up so much in those years. It is better than I could expect. The twinkies (horizontal bumps) at lemans that launch you into the air don't. People have been saying that there is no force feedback while using a wheel... not true, I have a G27 wheel and racing a F1 around nur you feel more than you could imagine from looking at the track. This is a sim, casual weekend racers beware! This game is really everything we wanted from forza and GT, Rain, Night racing, lights, physics, absolute carnage! True Aerodynamics, Tyre wear and fuel on or off are seperate! Endurance racing, parts will fail and break like they actually do IRL! This game is really out standing! It looks amazing I don't have it turned up to ultra yet because I only have a GTX 650Ti :(. All in all this game is what we asked and begged for for years and years never to get it. WELL DONE SLIGHTLY MAD! I cannot wait to see what is in store for us!

reviewText:
UPDATE as of 6/4/2016:

In my previous review, I did not recommend this game because it kept freezing in the same spots, and game performance was spotty in the last couple weeks.

As it turns out, these were indications of a Hard Disk Failure; essentially not the games fault. In my old review I thought the performance issues were from the game, when it was really my hard disk giving up the ghost. In any case, here is what I think about the game:

PROS:
- The game is beautiful, and the locations look faithfully rendered. I've actually been to both Laguna Seca and the northern parts of CA Route 1, and I can say that they really spent some time on getting details right, although I feel as though some of the locations are holdovers from NFS Shift and Shift 2, like the Nordschliefe.

-The Cars look good and perform well, and they sound pretty faithful. Although, I feel a lot of the cars they are releasing for DLC should have been included from the beginning instead of being part of specialized packs.

CONS:
- There are a few bugs. Every once in a while, the car decides that it want's to do it's own thing and run into a wall when I gently nudge the joystick (I bet that doesn't happen on a wheel). Other times, I've run into an invisible wall, or clipped something invisible. That doesn't happen often though.

- The handling model still needs some work. Sometimes the cars feels like they're breaking traction and they're skating around, making them a little more difficult to control. Other times, they aren't responsive until you turn too much and then end up backwards and facing the rest of the pack. You'll need to tweak the controls to your liking, but there is still that level of unpredictability.

- The DLC packs. I understand that this is a way to keep interest in a game and make more revenue, but when the game was first released, the car list made me go meh". There wan't really any cars that I was itching to drive except for a handful
date: since a lot of racing games have the same cars. They should have had the cars from some of the DLC packs from the beginning
recommended: instead of trotting them out pack by pack. Also
hoursPlayed:
for such an anglo-centric game why are there no TVRs? I would love to drive a faithfully rendered Tuscan Speed 6. Or a Cerbera Speed 12.

Final Thoughts:

Project Cars is exactly what it says on the box...er..Store Page. It's a graphical powerhouse of a racing sim aimed at people who want to have faithfully rendered cars and tracks. It's a game about the cars
voteText: not necessarily about the racing I feel. Even though they billed it as the next major racing sim
helpfulPercent: when you make an achivement in the game
votesHelpful: it doesn't really feel like an achievement. This is probably because all of the cars are unlocked in the very beginning
votesTotal: meaning that you don't unlock car classes the farther you go in your career. I feel as though thats a very important thing to have
votesFunny: as now there's no real incentive to complete the career mode.\n\nInstead
commentsCount: I end up spending most of my time on my home tracks (Laguna Seca and CA Route 1) with some of my favorite cars in single races or time trials. In that case
column16: this game is closer to the Test Drive series of games than it is a full on racing sim.\n\nStill
column17: taking a McLaren on the Coastal Highway isn't a bad thing at all."
